item.title: Bond Auctions Are Turning Into Wall Street’s Most-Watched Events
item.description: The big date on the calendar is a Treasury sale of $22 billion of 30-year bonds.
item.dc:creator: Liz Capo McCormick, Michael McKenzie, Alexander Nicholson

item.title: Tailscale Founder Talks Future IPO as Revenue Surges on AI Adoption
item.description: Canadian software networking startup Tailscale Inc. is sketching out a long-range plan to go public after unexpectedly becoming a beneficiary of the artificial intelligence boom and quickly doubling its valuation to $1.5 billion.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Seal

item.title: Stocks Hold Steady as Investors Eye US-China Talks: Markets Wrap
item.description: Stock futures held firm on Monday as investors set out to monitor talks between the US and China in London for signs that trade tensions between the two biggest economies might be cooling. The dollar fell.
item.dc:creator: Andre Janse Van Vuuren

media:content.media:description: Global Market Strategist Anna Rathbun discusses the impact of a rare earths deal between the U.S. and China, and how the feud between Elon Musk and President Trump shook up Tesla shares. She speaks with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.”

item.title: Malaysia to Expand Services Tax From July 1 to Trim Deficit
item.description: Malaysia is expanding its sales and service tax to include the construction and financial services sectors effective July 1, according to the Finance Ministry.
item.dc:creator: Ram Anand, Anuradha Raghu, Anisah Shukry

media:content.media:description: A construction site in Kuala Lumpur. Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan’s Taiyo Oil Imports Russian Crude on US-Sanctioned Tanker
item.description: The Japanese oil refiner Taiyo Oil Co. is taking delivery of a cargo of Russian crude on a tanker that’s blacklisted by both the US Treasury and the European Union.
item.dc:creator: Julian Lee, Tsuyoshi Inajima

media:content.media:description: The US-sanctioned oil tanker Voyager carries a cargo of crude from Russia’s Sakhalin 2 project to Japan.

item.title: US Treasuries Win Some Respite as Key 30-Year Auction Looms
item.description: US Treasuries trimmed last week’s losses, winning some respite ahead of Thursday’s auction of 30-year debt that will offer a fresh test of demand for the beleaguered securities.
item.dc:creator: Alice Gledhill, Sujata Rao

item.title: An Empire Built on Paper Looks to Benefit From Trump’s Trade War
item.description: Suzano’s buying spree, including a Kimberly-Clark deal, shows how executives in Latin America’s largest economy can work through fraught geopolitics.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Gamarski, Dayanne Sousa

media:content.media:description: A Suzano SA pulp plant in Jacarei, Brazil, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025.

item.title: HarbourView, KKR Ink $500 Million Financing Backed by Music
item.description: HarbourView Equity Partners, the investment firm that owns music royalties for artists including Fleetwood Mac and Wiz Khalifa, has raised $500 million in debt financing from vehicles managed by KKR & Co., according to a statement reviewed by Bloomberg News.
item.dc:creator: Michelle F Davis

item.title: Veteran Kotak Fund Manager Lakshmi Iyer Set to Join Bajaj Group
item.description: Lakshmi Iyer, a veteran fund manager at India’s Kotak Mahindra Group, has quit after over twenty years at the firm, people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Subhadip Sircar, Saikat Das

item.title: Japanese Investors Offload Most German Bonds Since 2014
item.description: Japanese investors sold the largest amount of German government bonds in a decade in April as the securities rebounded from a selloff the previous month spurred by fiscal concerns.
item.dc:creator: Masaki Kondo

item.title: South African Clothing Retailers Plan More Stores, Defying Economic Growth Outlook
item.description: South African clothing retailers are adding hundreds of new stores in the next year, even as the continent’s most-industrialized economy downgrades its economic growth forecast.
item.dc:creator: Janice Kew

media:content.media:description: A retail store, operated by Pepkor Ltd., in Johannesburg. Photographer: Waldo Swiegers/Bloomberg

item.title: China’s Copper Boom Tested as Miners Squeeze Smelters
item.description: The unrelenting expansion of Chinese copper processing capacity over the past few years has now become a global headache, as smelters scramble to secure the ore they need to produce the vital industrial metal.
item.dc:creator: Martin Ritchie, Winnie Zhu

media:content.media:description: Worker handles copper plates in a copper electrolysis plant at the Zijinshan mine, operated by Zijin Mining Group Co., in Longyan, China, on Monday, Sept. 23, 2024. Zijin Mining is vying with the largest Western producers for a spot among the top ranks, even as geopolitical tensions worsen.

item.title: Builder Seazen Mulls Up to $300 Million Offshore Bond Offering
item.description: Seazen Group Ltd. is considering raising $200 million to $300 million through a 2.5-year dollar bond offering, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Cai, Qingqi She

media:content.media:description: A housing project under construction in Zunyi, Guizhou province, China, on Thursday, June 15, 2023. Halfway through 2023, China is facing a confluence of problems: Sluggish consumer spending, a crisis-ridden property market, flagging exports, record youth unemployment and towering local government debt. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: China Enters Bull Market Into Trade Talks: 3-Minute MLIV
item.description: Guy Johnson, Lizzy Burden and Paul Dobson break down today's key themes for analysts and investors on "Bloomberg: The Opening Trade." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Taiwan Exports to US Hit Record as Two Sides Talk Trade
item.description: Taiwan’s exports to the US jumped to a record, surging as companies fired off shipments before any tariffs hit — gains that come as the two sides try to hammer out a trade deal.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee, Betty Hou

media:content.media:description: An image of a semiconductor wafer. Photographer: I-Hwa Cheng/Bloomberg

item.title: Oil Holds Ground Ahead of Fresh Round of US-China Trade Talks
item.description: Oil held onto a weekly gain as a renewed round of US-China trade talks offered the potential for reduced global tensions.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley, Sarah Chen

item.title: Zambia Seeks Carmakers to Make EV Components Near Copper Mines
item.description: Zambia has held talks with carmakers to entice suppliers to build electric-vehicle components plants near its copper mines.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hill

media:content.media:description: A worker moves stacks of copper plates ready for shipping at the Mufulira refinery, operated by Mopani Copper Mines Plc, in Mufulira, Zambia.

item.title: Octopus Ventures' CEO Erin Platts Speaking at London Tech Week
item.description: Octopus Ventures CEO Erin Platts says the global venture capital and private equity ecosystem "continue to be constrained." Speaking to Bloomberg TV's Tom Mackenzie on the sidelines of the London Tech Week, Platts noted that stagnation around exits is one of the key areas that is making it difficult for new investments going into founders. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Europe Must Defend Rule of Law Standards, ECB’s Elderson Says
item.description: Europe can foster economic well-being and help increase the euro’s global role by adhering to and even strengthening rule of law standards, European Central Bank Executive Board member Frank Elderson said.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Alessandra Migliaccio

item.title: Oil & Gas Deals Are Tanking. The World’s Top M&A Law Firm Has Been Here Before
item.description: Kirkland & Ellis spent a decade building a billion dollar-plus energy and infrastructure business and becoming the top legal adviser for US oil and gas deals. It was perfectly placed to benefit from Donald Trump’s “drill, baby, drill” agenda.
item.dc:creator: David Carnevali

item.title: BlackRock: European Fixed Income 'Good Place' to Be Now
item.description: BlackRock's EMEA iShares fixed income strategy head Vasiliki Pachatouridi discusses investors' sentiment for US bonds. "It's hard to imagine portfolios without US assets," Pachatouridi tells Bloomberg Television. "However, I am seeing particularly here in Europe, investors looking to diversify income, particularly with European fixed income." She also discusses what to expect from the Federal Reserve in the coming weeks and months. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Morgan Stanley, Goldman See Resilient Economy Supporting Stocks
item.description: Wall Street strategists are growing optimistic about US stocks, with forecasters at Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs Group Inc. the latest to suggest resilient economic growth would limit any pullback over the summer.
item.dc:creator: Sagarika Jaisinghani

media:content.media:description: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Monday, May 19, 2025. A renewed wave of dip buying fueled a rebound in stocks from session lows, with traders trying to look past the US downgrade by Moody’s Ratings that has sent bond yields climbing and weakened the US dollar.

item.title: Chinese Stocks in Hong Kong Enter Bull Market Before US Talks
item.description: Chinese shares trading in Hong Kong entered a bull market on Monday, as planned talks between the US and China fueled a wider sense of relief among investors.
item.dc:creator: Winnie Hsu, Lin Zhu

item.title: Vladislav Zubok on What the Cold War Actually Was
item.description: And are we in a new one?
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: A man walks along the West Berlin side of the Berlin Wall in 1962.

item.title: Yield Hunters Fuel $331 Billion Wave of Emerging Bond Sales
item.description: Strong demand from yield-hungry investors is driving a surge in developing-world bond sales as borrowers race to secure financing ahead of any further wobbles in global markets.
item.dc:creator: Vinicius Andrade, Zijia Song

item.title: Japan Should Use Asia Trade Bloc in US Talks, Party Chief Says
item.description: Japan should take a bigger role in a regional free trade agreement and use its expansion as a bargaining tool in tariff negotiations with the US, the leader of the country’s largest opposition party said on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

item.title: Lone Star’s Novo Banco Said to Get Bids From BPCE, CaixaBank
item.description: Lone Star’s Portuguese lender Novo Banco SA attracted two bids from French banking group BPCE and CaixaBank SA of Spain, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Swetha Gopinath, Jorge Zuloaga, Joao Lima

media:content.media:description: A customer uses an automated teller machine (ATM) at a Novo Banco SA bank branch in Lisbon, Portugal, on Friday, March 14, 2025. Home prices in Portugal, one of Europe’s hottest property markets, are expected to continue rising in 2025 on the back of increasing foreign demand and lackluster supply, according to DBRS Morningstar.

item.title: China’s Short-End Bonds Rally Amid Debate on Likely PBOC Trading
item.description: China’s short-end sovereign bonds rallied as heavy purchases by state banks spurred a debate among traders on whether the central bank was behind the move.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Wenjin Lv, Shulun Huang, Iris Ouyang

item.title: FTSE 100 Live: London’s Stock Market Set to Lose Another Tech Firm
JSDA Said to Probe Brokerages on Unsuitable Japanese Bond Sales
item.description: A Japanese securities industry group is probing brokerages on inappropriate bond selling practices amid surging investor demand for higher-yielding corporate debt.
item.dc:creator: Takahiko Hyuga
